newsitem.title: USA: Disney publishing unit may fetch $2.5 bln.
newsitem.headline: Disney publishing unit may fetch $2.5 bln.

text.p: Walt Disney Co on Tuesday said it planned to explore options related to the publishing operations of Capital Cities/ABC, including a possible sale of the business.

Industry analysts said the assets, which include a variety of newspapers and industry publications such as Women's Wear Daily, Automotive Marketing and Institutional Investor, could fetch as much as $2.5 billion.

A spokesman for Disney said the entertainment giant has received interest from a variety of companies looking to build up their publishing operations, but he declined to be specific. Among the options under consideration by Disney are a swap for other assets or a possible spin-off.

Cruttendon, Roth analyst Jeff Logsdon said the operations, which generate between $240 million and $250 million a year in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amoritization, could fetch as much as $2.5 billion in an auction, leaving Disney to focus its resources on other areas.

"From Disney's standpoint, I think there are very little obvious synergistic benefits to these assets," Logsdon said. He said it was unlikely that Women's Wear Daily or Institutional Investor could fit into a strategy of exploiting the Mickey Mouse brand around the world.
Earlier, Disney said it and Comcast Corp agreed to acquire Time Warner Inc's stake in the cable channel E! Entertainment Television. Analysts estimated Disney's investment at about $320 million.
Jessica Reif, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said the move was a cheap way for Disney to acquire another cable channel at a time when access to subscribers has been commanding hefty premiums.
"They're paying roughly $12 to $13 per subscriber," she said. "New networks are offering more than that just to get on -- and this is a profitable network."

The Capital Cities/ABC publishing operations are part of the company's Creative Content segment. The unit is involved in printing and distribution of daily and weekly newspapers, specialized industry publications and a range of consumer and special-interest publications.
